Chapter 1: Welcome to the World of Medical Marijuana (partial)

Note: Space on this page doesn't allow me to share this entire chapter, so I'm excerpting only part of it here.

When I first became a medical marijuana patient, I was shocked at how effective it was at quelling symptoms that I’ve suffered with for years. The results I experienced, from the very first day I took it, were dramatic. I’d heard lots of great things about medical marijuana over the years but I really didn’t expect it to be that beneficial.

As medical cannabis quickly became my lifeline to greater well-being, I realized that I had been stuck in stereotypes fostered by decades of slanted and incorrect ideas about this gift from Nature – and I started to see it as the miracle herb that so many people have long proclaimed it to be.

I was curious about why it was so effective for me and disappointed that I hadn’t tried it sooner – so I began to research this much maligned herb. The more I learned about marijuana, the more complex – and fascinating and unique – it was. I found myself navigating a confusing maze that was filled with unfamiliar terminology, numerous types of cannabis products to choose from, and very little specific direction on the best options for me.

Marijuana has been called a sacred herb, a super-herb, a Goddess herb, a master herb. Nature made it unique among all of her offerings. As with other herbs and plants, it is imbued with compounds that work together synergistically. However, it is distinguished in the world of botanicals because no other plant seems to have so many wide-ranging, health-promoting qualities. Hundreds of studies around the world, many of them within the last two decades, confirm a huge number of beneficial effects that marijuana has on the body and, in some cases, also the mind.

Among the many things I learned is that most of the medicinal strains of cannabis are very different from the strains that recreational users prefer. And that makes sense. The recreational user’s goal is generally to achieve the psychoactive “high” or “stoned feeling” that most people associate with it, while – for many medicinal cannabis patients – the “high” is an unwanted side effect.


My Experience Becoming a Medical Marijuana Patient

As a resident of California with verified medical needs, I could have qualified as a medical marijuana patient when it first became legal in the state in 1996. But, like many others, I didn’t pursue it because the federal government continued to wage a war on this amazing herb. Over those years, many Californians learned the hard way that their state law didn’t protect them from seizure and prosecution by the federal government. Many growers, dispensary owners, patients, and parents of patients who are minors ended up in prison, with a criminal record for the rest of their lives. News reports of those incidents scared many potential patients – like me – away from even trying this herb. As of this writing, news stories of these “crackdowns,” including seizures and arrests, still occur throughout the world, although not nearly as often. Thankfully, the situation is improving and cannabis is now available to many patients who have not had access to it in the past.

As I continued to study cannabis as a medicine, I was shocked to learn so much that I didn’t know – but felt I should have known. I have written on holistic health and complementary modalities off and on for several decades and I thought I actually knew quite a bit about these topics, including the subject of herbal medicine. My personal health choices have always veered away from pharmaceutical drugs as much as possible, preferring the most natural and holistic treatments to the potential negative side effects that are part and parcel of most pharmaceuticals. At one point in time, I didn’t even have a pain reliever like aspirin in my house because I didn’t want to take pharmaceutical drugs unless I felt it was needed as a last resort. Then I came to understand that – just as the side effects of a drug are a stress on the body – so is pain. Over time, as my health condition became much more challenging, I took over-the-counter pain medications to help me sleep at night and always got up during the night to take more when the drugs wore off. I alternated from one type to another to minimize the potential for negative side effects and my doctor frequently did blood tests since some of these drugs can cause serious liver problems. I had become much less judgmental about pharmaceuticals, but continued to be cautious, always preferring the natural route when possible.

One day, in desperation to feel better, I finally decided to ask my beloved doctor if she felt medical marijuana might help me. Over a year earlier, she had prescribed a pharmaceutical drug to help me sleep at night and I acquiesced because the constant pain and exhaustion were unrelenting. Eventually, over time, she added two more drugs to my nightly regimen, all with the goal of a good night’s sleep. Combined, the sleeping pill, painkiller, and muscle relaxant led to better sleep than I had experienced in a long, long time. I knew that she was focused on resolving the problems that caused my need for these drugs – always seeing them as a short-term solution while she also treated me for sleep apnea and with trigger point injections for muscle spasms. Nevertheless, my doctor and I were both concerned about the addictive qualities of these pharmaceutical drugs.

At the time of this appointment with my doctor, which was about a year after she had first prescribed the three drugs, I had been taking all of them much longer than she had planned. But every attempt I made to go off even one of them would make sleep more elusive. In addition, over time, my body had become tolerant to them so they had stopped giving me the results I so desperately needed. Most nights I woke up after about three hours and needed to take more pills. Then I would be awake for an hour or two in the middle of the night while I waited for the new round of drugs to kick in so I could get a bit more sleep before morning.

Knowing that I had been on these drugs much longer than my doctor wanted, I gently treaded onto the topic of medical marijuana with her. I greatly respect her for many reasons, including her integrative approach of combining Western medicine with alternative modalities and treatments. But I did not have any idea how she’d answer this question and was surprised at her immediate and positive response, almost as if it was she who brought up the subject of medical marijuana instead of me. 

My doctor smiled and told me she liked the idea and thought it might help. She then told me that she had a patient who was having excellent results with cannabis. She asked if I knew it was available in capsules? No, I didn’t. But that was intriguing and I really liked the idea because smoking a joint didn’t appeal to me. Taking a capsule, now that’s easy! My doctor then gave me a referral to another doctor from whom I got the official state medical marijuana recommendation, opening the door to this whole new world and, most importantly, opening the door to less pain and better sleep the very first night I tried it.

I was thrilled that I was able to replace three pharmaceutical drugs with one little capsule of cannabis extract. And that one little capsule worked better than the drugs. The more I studied cannabis, the more I realized that in order to really understand it, I would have to set aside all of the old negative stereotypes that I had heard all of my life. I searched books and numerous websites and queried people who might be in the “know” for the specific information that would help me understand how it works and why it appears to be so much more efficacious in healing than hundreds of other botanicals that are used around the planet. As I share some rather extraordinary facts about this healing herb, I suggest that you rethink it too. Even if you know a lot about marijuana, so much is changing that there’s a good chance that you’ll find many new-to-you facts on these pages.

I learned that the naturally-produced chemical compounds in cannabis bring balance and harmony to all of the body’s systems. (I’ll discuss these chemicals in greater depth in Chapter 7.) However, there’s no guarantee that two people with the same diagnosis and the same symptoms will find the same cannabis product to be equally efficacious. Each strain has a different chemical profile based on its own unique genetics and the conditions in which it was grown – a different ratio or proportion of the hundreds of the chemicals that are naturally produced by the plant. The two most prominent chemicals are THC, the chemical that causes the psychoactive “trip” or “high,” and CBD, which is considered to have many additional healing benefits. Another variable that impacts the efficacy from individual to individual is the fact that each body’s chemistry is different. Two people who have the same diagnosis and the same symptoms may find that the same strain of cannabis medicine is efficacious for both of them – or they may find greater benefit from two very different strains.

About 18 months into my medical cannabis adventure, I learned firsthand how different strains can deliver quite different healing benefits. Up until that time, I was very grateful for the benefits that I had received from a product that is high in THC, the chemical that causes the psychoactive “trip” or “high” that many associate with cannabis. Because this product helped to quell the pain associated with muscle spasms, it also improved my sleep. And I fully expected that, over time, I would experience more symptom relief and a greater level of healing overall.

While many pharmaceutical drugs focus only on symptom relief, a medicinal herb sometimes goes beyond symptom relief as it heals the body on a deeper level. This deep-healing potential can take time – but most of us are willing to be patient as we welcome the trajectory of feeling better and better over time. However, sometimes herbs surprise us by delivering fast results. And, from my perspective, there’s another factor behind all healing. Beyond the realm of medicines and treatments, as a spiritual counselor I want to point out that, from a mind-body-spirit perspective, healing doesn’t have to take time. Like me, you have probably heard stories of healings that have no explanation other than miraculous. I simply ask you to consider the possibility that if one person can tap into a miraculous healing, you can too.

When I heard media reports of the amazing healing benefits that some patients experienced with newly available strains that are extremely low in THC and high in CBD, I wanted to try one of them. I was primarily interested because extremely-high CBD products do not cause psychoactivity like THC does. The lack of psychoactivity can be helpful for any patient who finds that the high or stoned feeling from THC makes it difficult to fully function during the day. But for me there was another factor as well. My legs are a bit wobbly due to the condition I’ve been diagnosed with – and THC makes them more wobbly. So, up until that time, symptom relief during the day had eluded me – and, with rare exceptions, I took cannabis at bedtime only.

Most people find that their body builds a tolerance to the psychoactive effects of THC when they continually take it over a period of time – so they don’t get as high as in the past. However, I’m one of the rare individuals who has achieved very little tolerance to the THC in cannabis. Even after a couple of years, more than a tiny amount of THC makes me too wobbly to feel safe using it in the daytime.

I didn’t really expect anything miraculous from this new cannabis product; I just wanted a product that would help quell symptoms during the day. What happened was a big surprise. The day after I started taking the high-CBD, extremely low-THC product, I didn’t cough. In addition to other symptoms, a chronic debilitating cough had plagued me for 25 years – but that day I woke up and didn’t cough at all. A number of doctors had attempted to treat this cough over the years; however, without any success. Eventually, I found a nutritional supplement that lessened the frequency of the cough by about fifty percent; however, it was still a daily problem.

Since the two different products – made from different strains of cannabis, and manufactured by different companies – helped me in different ways, I started taking both on a daily basis. At that point, I had already written the first draft of this book and had done a ton of research. I had also seen dramatic reports on television documentaries of very sick children getting absolutely no relief from medical cannabis – until they were given a very specific strain that proved to be almost miraculous from the very first dose onward. I knew – at least I knew intellectually – that each strain has different healing benefit.

The new high-CBD capsule product didn’t help with muscle spasms and pain – so using it as my only cannabis medicine wasn’t an option. But the fast and dramatic improvement in the cough astounded me. Clearly, the particular chemical profile of that cannabis product gave me a different set of benefits from the high-THC product. That experience really opened my eyes and helped me understand how important it is to experiment with different forms and types of cannabis even if you think you are already being helped as much as possible. Remember, different strains have different benefits. That’s why it is helpful to consult with doctors and other experts who are knowledgeable about cannabis, try new strains and new products, and experiment with dosage in order to get the most healing benefit possible.

Much more recently, I have been able to obtain capsules that contain raw cannabis oil that does not cause any psychoactivity for me, so I can take them any time of the day or night without feeling groggy, wobbly, or at all high. This raw cannabis oil is the best product yet for me for symptom relief. It is considered “raw” because it is manufactured through a cold processing method – which means that it is non-psychoactive, except in rare cases. That’s because almost all of the THC that it would normally contain is present in a different chemical form called tetrahydrocannabinolic acid or THCa, a biosynthetic precursor to THC. Note that the “a” at the end of THCa stands for “acid.” When cannabis is exposed to heat, a process called decarboxylation converts the THCa to THC. But, as long as it is raw, it contains THCa, which has its own set of healing and symptom relief benefits, different from those of THC, giving any raw cannabis product additional advantages. Raw cannabis also contains a precursor form of CBD called CBDa, which provides different benefits from those of CBD. (Please note that most raw cannabis products DO contain small amounts of THC and CBD, but they are often so small that they may not be quantifiable.)

Some months ago I asked a greatly respected medical marijuana expert what he recommended for the condition I have been diagnosed with. He suggested a 2:1 ratio of CBD to THC – and my hunt ensued. While there are many medical cannabis products on the market, at the time I wasn’t able to locate any that were a 2:1 CBD to THC. In that situation, the only option is to try products that come closest. At the time, the closest I found was a 3:1 product – but it didn’t provide symptom relief. In the world of medical marijuana, a lack of success doesn’t necessarily mean the recommendation is wrong; it may mean that you need to give the product more time and/or tweak your protocol. Or it’s possible that it’s not the best product for you and it’s best to look for a different one.

As you’ll learn in more detail in later chapters, two different products that contain the exact same ratio of CBD and THC may give you very different results. That’s because, in addition to the CBD and THC, there are many other factors involved in any one product’s efficacy, including its potency, the dosage taken, and the hundreds of other chemicals in the plant which are present in smaller amounts – and in different ratios in each strain.

I was delighted when I obtained the raw cannabis oil capsules that I mentioned above, which is a 3:1 CBDa to THCa product. This product gives me the most symptom relief during the daytime of any products I have yet tried. Even though it’s not in the 2:1 CBD to THC ratio that was recommended to me, it is the closest I have obtained so far in a product that actually helps me. I appreciate the benefits that I am getting from this raw oil product – no psychoactivity and CBDa and THCa, which bring their own unique benefits. Like many patients, I have also learned to “tweak” my protocol by combining products. For example, a small amount of a high-THC product along with the 3:1 CBDa to THCa product is closer to the recommended 2:1 CBD to THC ratio than either product on its own. That combination seems to provide a bit more symptom relief and, I find that when I take a small amount of THC along with high-CBD product, the psychoactivity is lessened.

I continue to take a high-THC product at nighttime since, otherwise, muscle spasms and pain tend to keep me awake most of the night.

 

Your Brain Produces Its Own Marijuana

I’ve written about holistic health for over three decades and thought I knew a few things on the subject. However, I was in for a surprise when I learned one of the main reasons that scientists believe that cannabis is so healing: In the 1990s, researchers discovered that there are natural chemical compounds in cannabis that match receptors in the cells of our own bodies – referred to as “Your Brain’s Own Marijuana” in the title of a Scientific American article. Many believe that it is this link between the chemicals in the plant and those in the cells of our own bodies that makes cannabis so unique, so good at quelling symptoms and, in some cases, also bringing healing to health problems in the body and mind. In fact, the cells in the body that are a match for the cannabinoids in the cannabis plant were named endocannabinoids. ...

A healthy immune system supports the body’s individual cells as they repair themselves or replace themselves when they are damaged. Receptors, which are structures located on the surface of a cell or inside a cell – such as enzymes, neurotransmitters, or viruses – are a vital part of this “repair or replace” process. They act like receivers and give instructions to the cells to take a specific action, such as dividing, dying and replacing themselves, or allowing a specific substance into the cell or out of the cell. All of these actions occur constantly in the body as a process of normal cell functions.

Different strains of cannabis target different receptors in the body. Receptor sites on the surface of cells can lock onto certain molecules when they come along, basically working like locks and keys. Just like the front door of your home, a receptor can only be unlocked by a key that fits into that specific type of lock. In this “lock and key” system, a key that “matches” a lock then carries a signal through the cell’s wall. Let’s look at the example of a receptor on the surface of a cell that can act as a messenger for the sensation of pain. There is a unique place on the surface of the cell where this receptor can dock. When the pain receptor docks on the cell, it’s like a key that fits into the lock and it then activates the pain signal. However, if the receptor is blocked, the pain signal does not get through. Without the receptor, there’s no key to unlock the door, so the sensation of pain does not occur because the “door” remains locked. Many pharmaceutical drugs work by blocking specific receptors. For example, when a person takes a pain-relieving drug, the drug stops the pain receptor from activating and the person no longer feels the pain. ...

Until recently, cannabis was the only plant in which receptors that match our internal endocannabinoids had been found, making this herb incredibly unique and special. However, it didn’t make sense to me that there would be only one plant on this vast planet that was a match for our human endocannabinoid receptors. So I wasn’t surprised to find new research that indicates that chemicals from plants other than cannabis also directly interact with CB1 and/or CB2 receptors or have a chemical profile that is similar to the cannabinoids in cannabis. While research on this subject is in its infancy, the herb Echinacea has been found to be a match for some CB1 and CB2 receptors, with other plants also being investigated for their roles in promoting wellness via the human endocannabinoid system. Meanwhile, some new products combine cannabis and other healing botanicals such as Echinacea to increase the effects and curative properties of both herbs.

In Chapter 4 we will look at the connection between these receptors in the cells and the healing properties of cannabis that make it so powerful in healing bodily conditions.


The Role of Cannabis in Promoting Homeostasis

There’s a lot going on in your body simultaneously; it is set up for balance and harmony, with a goal of promoting maximum wellness. The body’s constant effort to maintain equilibrium among all of its internal processes and systems is called homeostasis, which the Merriam Webster Dictionary defines as “the maintenance of relatively stable internal physiological conditions (as body temperature or the pH of blood) in higher animals under fluctuating environmental conditions.” Early on in my research I learned that cannabis has some pretty awesome healing properties that promote this important function in the body.

As the body pursues optimal harmony and balance through homeostasis, it is constantly in the process of compensating. When one process or system is out of balance, another process or system compensates for the system that is not fully functioning. One example is the body’s ability to regulate temperature. As the body gets too hot or too cold, it will compensate to deal with the change in temperature. That’s why you sweat on a hot day; it’s the body’s way of cooling down.

The “repair and replace” mechanism within all of the cells in your body is also part of homeostasis. In fact, in the second that it took you to read this sentence, thousands of your cells have been automatically repaired or replaced with new cells. The body’s intelligence is mind-blowing and its ability to prioritize is what homeostasis is all about.

Imbalances in any of your body’s systems throw it off balance and out of whack and require compensating systems to restore balance. For most of us, these compensating mechanisms kick in automatically and keep us healthy, especially when we are young. If we get a cold or flu, our immune system goes to work and we are soon well again. If there is a toxin in the air, the body compensates, handles it, and we don’t even know about it because the body is programmed for wellness. It automatically compensates over and over to insure survival with the very best outcome. That is, unless it is overwhelmed and unable to handle the challenges that come its way, including infections, parasites, and environmental toxins. And, in addition to the tangible challenges that we deal with in the physical world, emotional traumas and negative thinking can also impact the body chemistry in negative ways and impact our health.

So how does homeostasis fit into the scheme of things when the subject is cannabis? Well, anything that helps the body deal with its imbalances will help it get back into homeostasis. While the ratios of the chemical compounds in cannabis vary from strain to strain, scientists have discovered a wide range of positive effects from these healing chemicals, including effects that are anti-proliferative, anti-inflammatory, anti-epileptic, anti-ischemic, anti-diabetic, anti-psychotic, anti-nausea, anti-spasmodic, antibiotic, anti-anxiety, anti-depressant, and anti-neoplastic (inhibiting development of malignant cells).

Even knowing all of this, it took a while for me to understand why cannabis is so significant and powerful – and why its healing properties are utilized by our bodies to such an amazing extent. Cannabis truly has a special and unique place in the world of botanicals. I frequently refer to it as a sacred healing herb because of the reverence I have for this gift from Nature. I will share lots more in these chapters about why and you will understand the reasons many doctors and other health professionals are now recommending cannabis to patients. 

Most medicinal herbs give us results over a period of time; their action is usually not very fast and we might not feel the beneficial effects for days, weeks, or even months. That is why it is important to give medicinal herbs time to do their work and not give up on them too soon. It is okay that it takes time because we understand that medicinal herbs heal on a causal basis. One of my mentors recently used the term “softer” to describe the healing we receive from herbs and many other holistic modalities. I liked that terminology because I believe herbs heal on a deeper level than pharmaceuticals – and that does feel softer to me. When we take a medicinal herb that benefits our body, it does so by getting to the root of problems and restoring balance.

Cannabis is considered to be a superhero in the world of medicinal herbs because of the positive side benefits that many patients experience. While it can take time for a major health issue to be resolved, most patients feel some of the beneficial effects of cannabis almost immediately, especially if they are astute in noticing their body’s responses. For example, you might immediately notice deeper, more relaxed breathing, and more relaxation in the muscles and skeletal system, which can result in better sleep, fewer bathroom visits during the night, improved lung function, and/or greater endurance and stamina. Cannabis can also quickly boost a patient’s mental attitude and it is known for giving quick relief to those suffering from nausea or lack of appetite.


Contradictory and Confusing Perspectives from the Powers That Be

Like so many others before me, once I had the official paper in my hand in which my state government sanctioned my right to use an ancient healing herb – without too much concern at that point in time of being arrested – I entered the maze. I was a stranger in a strange land. I had many questions: Where do I get the marijuana; what form of marijuana should I take (including smoking, vaporizing, capsules, edibles, suppositories, creams, salves, and other forms); what strain or type should I chose; what potency is right for me; and how often should I take it? Unless we have a knowledgeable physician or other ally, these are among the questions that we must all answer for ourselves. In most cases, we are expected to figure out a lot of details in this new and somewhat strange world and decide what is right for us as individuals. In fact, as of this writing, doctors in some jurisdictions are not allowed to tell you anything about it.

One has to be discerning and at least somewhat knowledgeable in order to sift through the mounds of dated, inaccurate, and biased information about cannabis that is presented as truth in books and on the Internet. One of the reasons for this glut of outdated, incorrect, and obviously skewed data was presented by Dr. Gupta on his CNN special, Weed. He reported that there have been over 20,000 studies on cannabis in the last couple of decades; however almost all of them – 94 percent – were focused on studying the deleterious effects and harm caused by marijuana, while only six percent of the studies were focused on the benefits. 

The biggest shock in the U.S. “war” against cannabis is that one branch of the government says cannabis has no medicinal value while, at the same time, a different branch of the U.S. federal government patented the cannabinoid CBD for its medicinal value. Clearly, there is a huge amount of evidence that cannabis has great medicinal value for an untold number of illnesses and conditions. But, as of this writing, the government still controls cannabis research in the U.S. and has allowed an extremely limited amount to be done, with most of it focused on disproving the medicinal value of marijuana. As a result, most doctors still refuse to recommend it due to the lack of “clinical trials.” It’s a Catch-22. The federal government does not allow clinical trials and, at the same time, argues that only clinical trials can establish proof of a medicinal value. As a result, to date, very few medical cannabis patients have a professional healthcare provider alongside them on their medical marijuana journey.

Anyone who knows how scientific studies are set up understands that it can be challenging to set up a totally unbiased study. If you want to study “deleterious effects and harm from marijuana,” that is what you are looking for – and it is likely that you will set up your research to focus on that. On the other hand, if you want to study “benefits from marijuana,” you will set up a study to give you data that proves the benefits of the herb. Unfortunately, for most of the last century, the U.S. government rarely looked for anything good about marijuana. The majority of the studies were done by the National Institute of Drug Abuse, a branch of the government that was focused almost exclusively on funding studies that would continue to demonize cannabis as a dangerous drug. Interestingly, some of the very top medical doctors who now promote cannabis as an important medicine were originally involved in research to debunk its medical benefits and were converted to when their studies proved its great merits. Within these chapters you will read about a couple of them.

Most of us have been brainwashed about the evils of “weed” all of our lives. Governments branded it as dangerous and made it illegal. In the U.S., the Justice Department put it on Schedule I of the Controlled Substances Act, which means it has no medicinal value and it is one of the most dangerous drugs available. The irony is that while some government agencies continue to view cannabis as a dangerous, illegal drug, other government agencies are well aware of its medicinal value. While people were still being thrown into prison for distributing or using marijuana for medicinal purposes, the government continued to run its own medical marijuana program out of the University of Mississippi. That program, which began in 1976, provides free cannabis each month to the patients who are enrolled in it. All these years later, patients who were originally part of this program are still receiving free cannabis from the United States government.

In addition to the government’s own contradictory marijuana giveaway program, the craziness continued when the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services obtained a patent on cannabinoids for their antioxidant and neuroprotective properties. Does this make sense – one government agency tells us that cannabis is a dangerous and illegal Schedule I drug, with no medicinal value, while another government agency not only acknowledges its medicinal value but also obtains a patent for it? Now how is that possible, you might ask? Isn’t it impossible to patent a plant? Apparently the U.S. federal government can do the impossible.

The abstract of U.S. Patent 6630507, entitled “Cannabinoids as Antioxidants and Neuroprotectants,” tells us exactly what the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services believes to be true about cannabis and its chemical compounds, cannabinoids. It says, in part: 

"Cannabinoids have been found to have antioxidant properties…. This new found property makes cannabinoids useful in the treatment and prophylaxis of a wide variety of oxidation associated diseases, such as ischemic, age-related, inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. The cannabinoids are found to have particular application as neuroprotectants, for example in limiting neurological damage following ischemic insults, such as stroke and trauma, or in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease and HIV dementia."

I am also fascinated by the section in the patent entitled “Detailed Description of Some Specific Embodiments,” which discusses more of what this “invention” – in this case, “compounds” found in the herb cannabis – provide to the body: 

"This invention provides antioxidant compounds and compositions, such as pharmaceutical compositions, that include cannabinoids that act as free radical scavengers for use in prophylaxis and treatment of disease. The invention also includes methods for using the antioxidants in prevention and treatment of pathological conditions such as ischemia (tissue hypoxia), and in subjects who have been exposed to oxidant inducing agents such as cancer chemotherapy, toxins, radiation, or other sources of oxidative stress. The compositions and methods described herein are also used for preventing oxidative damage in transplanted organs, for inhibiting reoxygenation injury following reperfusion of ischemic tissues (for example in heart disease), and for any other condition that is mediated by oxidative or free radical mechanisms of injury. In particular embodiments of the invention, the compounds and compositions are used in the treatment of ischemic cardiovascular and neurovascular conditions, and neurodegenerative diseases. However the present invention can also be used as an antioxidant treatment in non-neurological diseases."

In addition to this patent, a number of other patents have been granted by the U.S. government for the medicinal value of cannabis, including:

  • U.S. Patent 20130059018: PhytoCannabinoids in the treatment of cancer

  • U.S. Patent 5,538,993: Compounds according to the present invention are characterized by various beneficial properties such as analgesic, anti-emetic, sedative, anti-inflammatory, anti-glaucoma, and neuroprotective activities

  • U.S. Patent 6,448,288: Use of Cannabinoid compounds for inhibiting, inducing

  • U.S. Patent 4,876,276: Special use in cases of acute and of chronic pain

  • U.S. Patent 7,179,800: Useful for therapy, especially in the treatment of pain, inflammation and autoimmune disease

Clearly the U.S. government knows that cannabis is actually a safe, effective, and inexpensive medicine; not a dangerous drug with no medicinal value, as the Drug Enforcement Administration has classified it for so long.


A New Look at Old Stereotypes

Now let’s look at a couple of the stereotypes about cannabis. The stereotype that cannabis causes the “munchies” and leads to overeating may be true for some people when they take some cannabis products. But – again – it depends on the strain and the individual. Some people who are overweight lose weight with no effort on medical cannabis – while those who are underweight are often successful in gaining weight.

I have been overweight for most of my life. Even though I had dropped quite a bit of weight a few years earlier using a nutritional supplement and doing emotional healing work, at the point in time that I started taking cannabis, I was still overweight and had been stuck on a plateau for a couple of years. For the first six months or so that I took cannabis, I didn’t gain or lose weight. But then, after I started taking a high-potency cannabis oil product, which is now manufactured under the name Natur-Oil, I started losing weight with no effort at all at the rate of one to three pounds a month until I had lost about 30 pounds. I know that cannabis can help to balance the blood sugar and I assume that is one of the many ways it has helped in my body. Instead of getting the “munchies” and overeating, cannabis curbed my appetite and my desire for sweets and carbs. I didn’t diet, eliminate or limit any foods, or exercise more. I ate whatever I wanted and enjoyed every bite of everything I chose to eat, including sweets and carbs, finding that my body only wanted small amounts of them. That made weight loss easy. I was still rather shocked on those occasions when I didn’t even want a small serving of a yummy-looking dessert that was offered to me – but the fact that I didn’t WANT it and passed on it for that reason felt really good. I have continued on this trajectory – and I now feel that I’m “eating to live,” rather than “living to eat.” 

Another stereotype that’s prevalent among the public is that anyone who uses medical cannabis is a slacker who “just wants to get stoned.” I’m okay with people getting stoned if that is their choice, as long as they are responsible about it, but that is not my desire. My experience is that getting high is NOT the preference of most medical marijuana patients. Our goal is not to get high; our goal is to heal. Thankfully, as I mentioned above, for those of us for whom the high is undesirable, newer strains and forms of non-psychoactive cannabis are now available.

[As I mentioned earlier, Indiegogo doesn't provide enough space on this page to include all of Chapter 1.  I hope you have found the sections I have included informative.]
story_txt:
Medical Marijuana changed my life. Help me get the word out about
 why this herb is so amazing – and learn how it may help you or your loved one. 

 I wrote The Medical Marijuana Handbook:  A Patient's Guide to Holistic Healing with Cannabis  to
help patients navigate the often confusing maze that is the world of medical
marijuana – and I am asking your help to get it published.  Medical marijuana has helped me cope
with symptoms from a chronic lifelong condition far better than any pharmaceuticals I’ve used –  and I want everyone to
know about this option for symptom relief and for healing. 
Over the past few decades, I've coauthored 12 books with experts on holistic health, stress management, brain optimization, and other topics.  And now I'm passionate about telling everyone about the awesomeness of medical marijuana!  I wrote this book because I want other patients to understand the many 
complexities of this herb, including WHY scientists believe it works so 
well for so many. 
Most of the perks offered in this campaign include, in essence, the pre-purchase of  copies of the book, which will be sent when it is published in September.  Additionally, ALL contributors will receive a PDF of 3 chapters for FREE right away.  AND I have included part of Chapter 1 at the end of this campaign page so you don't have to wait to plunge in!
Since my goal is to educate the entire world on this topic – especially health professionals, politicians, and educators – some perks also include my "Get One, Give One" program in which contributors will be helping me send free copies of the book to thought leaders.  




When I first tried medical marijuana, I was desperate for something that would help ease the pain and 
discomfort
of my physical symptoms and not be addictive like the prescription drugs
 I was taking.  Those drugs had ceased being effective – and I
did not want to take stronger drugs,
which came with an increasing number of scary potential side effects. I was immediately surprised at HOW effective it was – and disappointed that I hadn’t tried it
sooner. Medical marijuana quickly became my lifeline to greater well-being. 
Medical marijuana is constantly in the news these days—and yet
when I talk to friends and family, as well as doctors, I find that few understand
what it really is, what it really does,
and WHY it is so effective for so many.  Many questions arise when starting on this journey, including: 


Why should I
consider medical marijuana, and is it right for me?

What health
issues can be helped by it?


What makes it
such a potent healing herb?

How and where
do I legally get the marijuana? 

What strain,
what form, what potency, and what dose is right for me?  


What do I tell
the kids about taking something that they’ve been told is illegal and wrong?


Unless
we have a knowledgeable ally, most patients must answer these questions for
ourselves—often, all on our own. In fact, in some jurisdictions, doctors aren’t allowed 
to tell you anything about medical marijuana.


Medical cannabis can help with these issues:




Decrease pain and inflammation 

Soothe nausea

Treat muscle spasms


Reduce anxiety


Stimulate appetite 

Induce better and more restful sleep

and so much more…

Who can be
helped by medical cannabis? 




Patients with acute health conditions that are life
     threatening.
     Cannabis has been shown to provide symptom relief for many patients and,
     for some, actual improvement in severe life-threatening health challenges.
     


Patients
     with chronic health issues. 
Many patients find that symptoms of
     chronic health concerns are quelled by cannabis, without the negative side
     effects of other medications.


Patients
     with sporadic health issues or injuries.
     Cannabis is also found to be efficacious for many common symptoms, such as
     pain, anxiety, difficulty sleeping, nausea, etc.



Health-conscious
     individuals who want to stimulate their body’s internal healing system
     with a regular maintenance dose of cannabis. 
Cannabis helps modulate or balance
     every human physiological system, including regulating immunity,
     inflammation, neurotoxicity, blood pressure, appetite, gastrointestinal
     function, and intraocular pressure. Therefore, many health-conscious
     individuals desire a small maintenance dose of medical cannabis to promote
     health and wellbeing.




Clearing Up the Confusion Around Medical Marijuana ...

The world of medical marijuana is filled with unfamiliar terminology, numerous types of cannabis products to choose from, and very little specific direction on the best options for each patient. One
has to be discerning and at least somewhat knowledgeable in order to sift
through the mounds of information that is presented as "truth" in books, articles and the Internet—a great deal of which is outdated,
inaccurate, or biased. Most people tend to think of medical marijuana as one
specific medicine, which gets you high, when in reality each strain of cannabis
is, in some ways, a different medicine from every other strain.  Treatment
options now include non-psychoactive (no "high"), smokeless, and
topical forms and formulations of cannabis, with many new strains
continually being created and bred for their specific healing qualities.

I
wrote The Medical Marijuana Handbook to answer your questions, soothe your
concerns, and give you the information you—or a family member or friend—need in
order to make informed decisions and effectively use medical marijuana. I
literally walk you by the hand through all that you need to know, drawing not only
from my own experience and research, but from interviews I’ve conducted with
health professionals, medical cannabis experts, and other patients. I’ve worked
hard to make sure this information is as up-to-date and accurate as possible. Even if you know a lot about cannabis, so much
is changing that there’s a good chance you’ll find many new-to-you facts in my
book. 






Here's What Leading-Edge Medical Doctors Say About Medical Cannabis



Dr. Sanjay Gupta: In a 2013 article entitled “Why I
Changed My Mind on Weed,” Dr. Gupta totally reversed his previous stand against
medical marijuana. He now says that cannabis has “very legitimate medical
applications” and “sometimes it’s the only thing that works.” CNN.com; August 9, 2013
Dr. Mehmet
Oz:"I grew up like most of
my generation believing that marijuana was something Satan was throwing at
Americans, a communist plot. But I think most of us have come around to believe
that marijuana is hugely beneficial when used correctly for medicinal
purposes," Larry King
Live, CNN, May 12, 2014
Dr. Lester
Grinspoon, Emeritus Professor of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School: “…
[marijuana] is extraordinarily safe – safer than most medicines prescribed
every day. If marijuana were a new discovery rather than a well-known substance
carrying cultural and political baggage, it would be hailed as a wonder drug.” “Marijuana
as Wonder Drug,” Boston Globe, March 1, 2007 

What It Will Take to Publish The Medical Marijuana Handbook



My book is fully written and in the stages of production. It is a
full-length book of approximately 75,000 words and will be published by September,
2015.  My goal is to raise $35,000 to publish and launch The
Medical Marijuana Handbook. Publishing costs of $20,000 include editing,
interior design and formatting for both print and eBooks, cover art, printing, and shipping.
Marketing costs of $15,000 include a website, short promotional videos for
YouTube, and book launch expenses.  

Stretch Goals


As I want to get this information into the hands of as many people as
possible, a stretch goal of $50,000 would allow me to hire a PR firm and
do some local and national advertising to raise awareness of the healing
properties of this amazing herb, help remove some of the stigma attached to it,
and get my book into the hands of the people who most need it.  
My dream is to place a full-page ad in The New York Times, and
through that ad give free eBook copies of The Medical Marijuana Handbook
to as many people as possible to help educate them about cannabis medicine.
Of course, like any New York real estate, a full-page ad comes with a high
price tag. So if I reach a stretch goal of $100,000, look out New York
Times! 
I envision my book in the hands of thought leaders –  health professionals, politicians, members of the judiciary, and educators – because I believe it will help them understand WHY cannabis should be available to all patients. Okay, so you may be thinking that getting the book into the hands of influential people doesn't mean they will read it.  And that's true.  They may not read the book, but maybe one of their relatives, their neighbors, or their coworkers WILL read it.  Each person who becomes educated about the truth of cannabis medicine helps to tip the balance a bit more for all of us.  And that brings us closer to a world in which the herb is available to all.
Please join me and together we will raise awareness. The more you know, the more you can help others understand!
The money raised from this campaign will enable me to roll The Medical
Marijuana Handbook out in a way this important topic deserves. 








Praise for The Medical Marijuana Handbook
"The medical uses of marijuana are
changing the lives of thousands of individuals and these applications will
continue to expand.  Norma Eckroate's The Medical Marijuana Handbook sheds
much-needed light on this rapidly evolving field.”  
— Larry Dossey, MD, author of ONE
MIND: How Our Individual Mind Is Part of a Greater Consciousness and Why It
Matters
"The Medical Marijuana Handbook provides an in-depth and personal
look into one of the leading untapped resources in modern medicine. In her
wonderful book, Norma Eckroate provides insights as both a patient and a
researcher on the history of cannabis, its benefits and applications, and
dosing. She also explains why cannabis is one of the most beneficial medicines
available today because of the unique and holistic ways that it heals. I highly
recommend this book to anyone who is on a healing journey.”      —John H. Hicks, MD 


"The Medical Marijuana Handbook is a 'must read'
for anyone who wonders if cannabis might be helpful for them. In this excellent
book, Norma Eckroate provides us with a layperson’s primer on the science
behind cannabis. The book is chock-full of practical information – and I
especially appreciate Eckroate’s holistic perspective and body-mind-spirit
approach. As a psychologist, it is intriguing to follow case studies and
reports of the efficacy experienced by medical cannabis patients for conditions
such as anxiety, attention disorders, bipolar disorder, and post-traumatic
stress disorder, among others. It is my sincere hope that this healing herb
will be more accessible to those for whom it can truly be a natural and effective
option."     
—Ronit Lami, PhD, psychologist and contributing author, Roadmap to Success
Perks

The Medical Marijuana Handbook is a full-length book (approx. 75,000 words) which will be published by September. It is completely written and currently in the production process. The FREE 3-chapter excerpt described in the next 
section will be sent to contributors within a couple of days of the date
 of their contribution.Perks that include copies of the eBook and/or print books will be sent when the book is published.  There will be several options for eBook formats; contributors will be given an option on which format they prefer before it is sent.  With the exception of books that are part of the "Get One, Give One" donation program that is described below, all print books in your selected perk will be sent to the same address.  Print books offered in each perk category are available to contributors with U.S. addresses only.  Get a FREE 3-Chapter Excerpt RIGHT NOW!
My number one goal is to share with EVERYONE how awesome medical cannabis is. If I had understood its awesomeness sooner, I
would have had greater symptom relief SOONER! 




I want LOTS of people to understand the truth about medical cannabis—so I decided to give a PDF of the first 3 chapters of this book to all contributors—and once you have the PDF, you can share it with anyone and everyone!
And you don’t have to contribute money to get these three chapters.  Just help me spread the
